title: [BUG] Changing text field in schema item doesn't enable the save and revert button
body:
Currently, when you only change the text field in the schema item, you cannot save or revert. You can only do that if you also changed the schema name. This is because of a bug introduced when trying to fix a eslint6 warning in #2912 . The fix in the PR made the textFieldChanged variable always false as long as you don't change all rows at the same time.

To reproduce:
Open any schema item/ create a schema item that has at least two rows. Change one field on one of the rows, the save and revert button isn't enabled until you change at least one text field on each row

title: Fix schema change detection on text field
body:
### Reasons for making this change

Currently, when you only change the text field in the schema item, you cannot save or revert. You can only do that if you also changed the schema name. This is because of a bug introduced when trying to fix a eslint6 warning in https://github.com/codalab/codalab-worksheets/pull/2912 . The fix in the PR made the textFieldChanged variable always false as long as you don't change all rows at the same time.

The correct way to fix the warning is to use the traditional loop https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58816244/debugging-eslint-warning-function-declared-in-a-loop-contains-unsafe-reference

### Test
Open an existing schema item, change any text field but not schema name, the save and revert button are now enabled again

### Screenshots
Before changing any text field, the save and revert are disabled
![Screenshot from 2021-02-27 15-09-31](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23012631/109402873-4475b580-790e-11eb-89c0-95436b2742fc.png)

After changing the text field, the save and revert are enabled
![Screenshot from 2021-02-27 15-09-45](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23012631/109402875-463f7900-790e-11eb-9152-e7890ef27da1.png)

title: Large bundles that can't fit in server memory cannot be downloaded by workers

labels.name: p1
labels.description: Do it in the next two weeks.

body:
**Describe the bug**

If a worker takes a dependency on a very large bundle (e.g. 3GB) that can't fit in the server's memory, the server is unable to transmit the dependency and thus the worker fails.

The issue is that in https://github.com/codalab/codalab-worksheets/commit/4cc81fc8142efef6b608d6677bec0e85565908b8#diff-2b2d1ef00e8805335562a7967af36158e9140f6c4a5039f3462517795e4d67f6R210-R218, some changes were made to the `gzip_file` function. Now, it does a `data = open_file(file_path).read()`, which attempts to read the entire file into memory---this isn't always going to work.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior :
1. Run a bundle on codalab.stanford.edu (host only has 4G memory) that depends on glove.840B.300d (3GB+ file)

**Expected behavior**
The worker downloads the file

**Server Log**
```
2020-11-03 23:19:02,245 Error on request by nfliu(0x9da95d34ca4d4b7a8b271859281d936c):

GET /bundles/0x58947c280ae341b9b270fcc2173dc951/contents/blob/

Query params:


Form params:


JSON body:
<none>

Local variables:
file_path='/juice/u/codalab/var/codalab/home/partitions/default/bundles/0x58947c280ae341b9b270fcc2173dc951'

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/codalab-worksheets/codalab/worker/file_util.py", line 214, in gzip_file
    data = open_file(file_path).read()
MemoryError

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/codalab-worksheets/codalab/server/rest_server.py", line 106, in wrapper

title: Workers getting assigned more bundles than they can run

labels.name: p1
labels.description: Do it in the next two weeks.

body:
**Describe the bug**
Workers are getting assigned more bundles than they can run. This manifests in the error message for PREPARING bundles "Unexpectedly unable to assign enough resources to bundle 0x6e4839f7f6014e4c9b7aa64a67762257: Requested more GPUs (1) than available (0 currently out of 1 on the machine)".

Doing some digging, I noticed the following pattern happening. The worker is a 1-gpu machine, and all bundles request 1 GPU---so the worker should be only able to run 1 thing at once. One case I found was that the worker was already running bundle `0x9575f85367564a6385e4abe96d14f8c4`, but got assigned `0x6e4839f7f6014e4c9b7aa64a67762257` as well. However, it can't run `0x6e4839f7f6014e4c9b7aa64a67762257`. This is what the BundleManager log shows:

```
2020-10-26 02:20:31,082 Starting run bundle 0x9575f85367564a6385e4abe96d14f8c4 on worker tahoma(4449)
...
2020-10-26 04:14:50,258 Bringing bundle offline 0x9575f85367564a6385e4abe96d14f8c4: No worker claims bundle
...
2020-10-26 04:15:15,851 Starting run bundle 0x6e4839f7f6014e4c9b7aa64a67762257 on worker tahoma(4449)
```

At this point, the worker is erroneously running both `0x9575f85367564a6385e4abe96d14f8c4` and `0x6e4839f7f6014e4c9b7aa64a67762257`. Seems like this happens when workers temporarily go offline, so their bundles are marked as offline, but they come back online in time for them to be assigned new bundles but not in time for the BundleManager to update the worker info to record that they're already running something.

**To Reproduce**
Unclear

**Expected behavior**
Bundles are not overassigned.

title: Fix the bug of upload not releasing keyboard shortcuts
body:
### Reasons for making this change

On a worksheet, hit 'a u' to trigger upload, select by press 'enter', but two upload menus will appear consecutively. 
The bug results from that `stopPropagation` allows other handlers on the same element to be executed, so another hidden upload menu will also be clicked when we press 'enter' later, and thus two menus appear consecutively, so I use `stopImmediatePropagation` instead, and it prevents every event from running.

### Related issues

fix #2364 

### Screenshots

![2364-upload](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34461466/93828920-42058600-fc21-11ea-8279-f5fa82e23be1.gif)
Works normally now.

title: Avoid conflicting worker resources
body:
### Reasons for making this change

When we precompute the available worker resources, we call `_deduct_worker_resources` twice to get the list of workers that the user owns and a list of CodaLab public workers. In `_deduct_worker_resources`, a deep copy of the worker list (with resources deducted) is returned back to the caller.

![deduct_called_twice](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16793796/90858900-f61ea300-e33b-11ea-9b8b-fcf79a5ed262.png)

When the root account of an instance runs an experiment, two identical lists of workers are precomputed, but only the resources of one of them gets modified as they are deep copies of each other (not by reference), which will eventually cause the over-assigning of bundles to workers.

This issue is reproducible on our `dev` environment with the stress test I've added in this PR, only if the stress tests are ran with the root account. This issue is not reproducible if any other user account is used. I think the reason why we don't see this issue in `prod` is because we don't usually use the root account to create runs.

The fix in this PR is to simply remove the deep copy logic in `_deduct_worker_resources`. I am not sure why the `deepcopy` was added, but it doesn't seem necessary. If it is necessary, I can add it back and use another solution, which is to aggregate and take the minimum between the two lists. With the change in this PR, the issue is no longer reproducible.

### Related issues

Potentially resolves #2746

title: [USER ISSUE] Can't upload bundle in fresh server
body:
**Describe the bug**
Following the [guide](https://codalab-worksheets.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Server-Setup/), I set up a custom server with the latest master branch on host. When I log in and try to upload a file, I see the following prompt:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2626883/89261184-7d50e480-d5e2-11ea-9fb7-cacf7a9486e0.png)

When I use the CLI to upload, I get a different error:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2626883/89261432-e9cbe380-d5e2-11ea-930b-c0167b60d94c.png)

I'm using the following config with the CLI:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2626883/89261497-0405c180-d5e3-11ea-9947-0b2523b43ddd.png)


**Codalab Information**
- *Your username*: codalab
- *Error message received from Codalab (if applicable)*: Missing metadata key link_url.
 - *OS (if on CLI)*: the server is on Amazon Linux 2.
 - *Browser (if on Web)*; Chrome

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior :
1. Launch a fresh EC2 host with Amazon Linux 2 image.
2. Launch an RDS database for mysql and use it in the mysql server config
3. Create an EFS file system for codalab home, link mount, bundle mount
4. Make sure that the security group setting let's them talk to each other
5. Open the browser and go to the IP address

**Expected behavior**
I expect the upload to succeed and the bundle to appear


**Additional context**
I left the above server running and you can visit the ip address with the default password to see the problem for yourself.

Below is the command I used to start the server.
```
./codalab_service.py start --mysql-root-password $MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD --mysql-password $MYSQL_PASSWORD --mysql-username $MYSQL_USERNAME --mysql-port $MYSQL_PORT --mysql-host $MYSQL_HOST --mysql-database $MYSQL_DATABASE --codalab-home $CODALAB_HOME --http-port 80 --worker-manager-type $WORKER_MANAGER_TYPE --worker-manager-aws-region $WORKER_MANAGER_AWS_REGION --worker-manager-aws-default-cpus $WORKER_MANAGER_AWS_DEFAULT_CPUS --worker-manager-aws-default-memory-mb $WORKER_MANAGER_AWS_DEFAULT_MEMORY_MB --worker-manager-max-cpu-workers $WORKER_MANAGER_MAX_CPU_WORKERS --worker-manager-max-gpu-workers $WORKER_MANAGER_MAX_GPU_WORKERS --link-mounts $CODALAB_HOME/links --server $SERVER --admin-email $ADMIN_EMAIL --bundle-mount $CODALAB_HOME/bundles
```

title: can't text/upload/run on a newly loaded worksheet
body:
To reproduce, create a new worksheet with one bundle on it.  Refresh the page.  Then click 'text', 'upload', or 'run'.  Nothing happens.  You have to select the last row for it to work.

This is because the focus is at -1 when the page loads.

In the past, we have appended new blocks to the worksheet, in concordance with what happens on the CLI.  However, this doesn't mesh well with the intuition that the cursor is right before the first item on the page, so the actually new blocks should be prepended to the worksheet.  Having a reverse chronological research log isn't itself a bad idea, but the problem is that the whole CodaLab model of always referring to the *last* bundle gets broken.

Perhaps a safe thing to do is only allow text/run/upload if the focus is not -1 on a non-empty worksheet, and always put a 'Go to end' button.

Or we can just have an as-is mentality and just prepend when focus is -1.

title: Dependencies sometimes cannot be found in the current working directory
body:
**Describe the bug**

It seems like, sometimes, dependencies aren't properly mounted.

Take this (failing) bundle: https://worksheets.codalab.org/bundles/0xfe7a2a4c16594c03890e4da87aad70d4

It runs a python script that expects `./train.json`. However, it fails because it cannot find `./train.json`:

```
06/19/2020 12:03:21 {'wv_file': 'glove.840B.300d.txt', 'wv_dim': 300, 'wv_cased': True, 'sort_all': True, 'threads': 32, 'batch_size': 64, 'pre_processing_type': 'fusion', 'train': 'train.json', 'dev': 'dev.json', 'output_path': 'preprocessed_data.pth', 'spacy_version': '1.9.0'}

    train = flatten_json(trn_file, proc_train)
  File "documentreader/prepro.py", line 77, in flatten_json
    with open(file) as f:
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'train.json'
```

However, if I mimic the bundle and rerun it again ( https://worksheets.codalab.org/bundles/0x39b13132359e4f6d9c100c71bdf139cf ) :

title: [USER ISSUE] - cl-competitiond fails if any one of the submission bundles are not accessible

labels.name: p3
labels.description: Do it some day.

body:
**Describe the bug**
The cl-competitiond script fails during a run if at least one run bundle has a private dependency. Based on the fetch order, the script either fails at the first mimic or runs a few bundles and then fails.

**Codalab Information**
- *Your username*: imalhi
- *UUID of worksheet where problem occurred*: local cli
- *Error message received from Codalab (if applicable)*: 404 Bundle not found
 - *OS (if on CLI)*: Mac Os, Ubuntu 18
 - *Codalab CLI Version (if on CLI)*: 0.5.13
 - *Browser (if on Web)* : N/A

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior :
1. Create a competition, or use an existing one
2. Make the src bundle of a submission bundle's upstream run bundle private.
3. Run cl-competitiond for the competition
4.  Script fails with a 404 error

**Expected behavior**
The script should skip the 404'd bundle and run the rest.

**Screenshots**
N/A

**Additional context**
I have a semi-working fix that uses a try-catch to ignore 404 errors when looping through submissions.

title: Single-file dataset uploads don't preserve executable permissions
body:
**Describe the bug**
Not sure if this is intended, but executable files, when mounted as dependencies (just the file itself), are not executable.

**To Reproduce**

```
$ touch test.sh

$ chmod +x test.sh

$ ls -al test.sh
-rwxr-xr-x 1 nfliu staff 0 Mar 21 20:30 test.sh

$ cl up test.sh -n test.sh
Preparing upload archive...
Uploading test.sh (0x21c2c6599378432985b2ad842f25ba9b) to https://worksheets.codalab.org

0x21c2c6599378432985b2ad842f25ba9b

$ rm test.sh

$ cl down 0x21c2c6599378432985b2ad842f25ba9b
Downloading test.sh(0x21c2c6599378432985b2ad842f25ba9b)/ => /Users/nfliu/git/ood-variance/test.sh
Received 0.00MiB [0.00MiB/sec]

$ ls -al test.sh
-rw-r--r-- 1 nfliu staff 0 Mar 21 20:31 test.sh
```

Note that the file was executable when uploaded, but not when downloaded. If you try to `cl run test.sh:test.sh ./test.sh`, the run fails with `/bin/bash: ./test.sh: permission denied`

**Expected behavior**
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.

I expected to be able to run the script.

**Additional context**

Pretty sure this works if you put test.sh into a folder, and then upload the folder...

title: Hosting WebApp on CodaLab - White Page of Death and Speed Issues

labels.name: p3
labels.description: Do it some day.

body:
**Describe the bug**

I'm trying to host a web app using CodaLab's netcurl functionality. However, when I try to navigate to the site (https://worksheets.codalab.org/rest/bundles/0x32012ac03152440f8b0b3b2ddbe67fe0/netcurl/8000/index.html) , and refresh the page a few times, the page stops loading altogether.

Furthermore, I'm noticing some problematic speed issues, especially as multiple users try to use the system. 

**Codalab Information**
- *Username*: siddk
- *UUID of worksheet where problem occurred*: 0xa3b3c03d52a14a31b9293c5980fdcd9c
- *UUID of problem bundle (please don't delete)*: 0x32012ac03152440f8b0b3b2ddbe67fe0 / https://worksheets.codalab.org/rest/bundles/0x32012ac03152440f8b0b3b2ddbe67fe0/netcurl/8000/index.html
- *Error message received from Codalab (if applicable)*: No Error Message
 - *OS (if on CLI)*: N/A
 - *Codalab CLI Version (if on CLI)*: N/A
 - *Browser (if on Web)*; Chrome

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior :
1. Go to https://worksheets.codalab.org/rest/bundles/0x32012ac03152440f8b0b3b2ddbe67fe0/netcurl/8000/index.html
2. Refresh the Page multiple times (on Chrome or Firefox)
3. Eventually the page stops loading, and only serves an empty white page. However, if you switch to incognito mode, the page loads again (maybe some weird caching issue?)

**Expected behavior**
Page should load, and should load somewhat quickly every time a user navigates to the site.

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Additional context**

App is currently a combination of a React frontend (compiled into a static build) that is served via a Flask application (that implements other backend logic), run with the Gunicorn WSGI.

title: Certain sequence of worksheet actions and keyboard shortcuts causes previous text to get copied and repeated

labels.name: p3
labels.description: Do it some day.

body:
A bit troublesome to reproduce, but here are the steps to reproduce the issue:

1. Add a title to worksheet
2. Add some long text to the worksheet
3. Add a bundle using your mouse and hit Confirm
4. Rerun the bundle with your mouse by opening the previous bundle and hitting "Edit and Rerun"
5. This time add a bundle using `a r`. Type "echo goodbye" and hit CTRL + ENTER to save the bundle.
6. Upon saving see the new bundle being added + the text from step 2 getting repeated (for some odd reason). 

See the gif attached below. You can see the big block of text at the top of the worksheet getting copied and added to the worksheet.

![shortcut_bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16793796/76487406-9365ca80-63df-11ea-94e1-e35972c03473.gif)

title: bundle details not refreshing for run bundles
body: Create a new run bundle.  Hit 'enter' to show bundle details.  If 'enter' is hit before the bundle status changes to staged, then the bundle status in the bundle details panel that shows up doesn't update.  If 'enter' is hit after the bundle status changes to staged, then it will update reliably.

[USER ISSUE]Downloading dependencies using a codalabworker is very slow
body:
**Describe the bug**
We found that a codalabworker download dependencies very slowly, although we used the command line to upload `cl upload` quickly.

**Codalab Information**
- *Your username*: lrh001
- *UUID of worksheet where problem occurred*: 0xdcc8c840b5cd4243b6f90ade484aa9ae
- *UUID of problem bundle (please don't delete)*: 0x5c7f9b (failed), 0x86a7fe (ready), 0x90db97 (failed)
- *Error message received from Codalab (if applicable)*:

Failed to download Docker image: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='hub.docker.com', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /v2/repositories/lrh000/ubuntu/tags/?page=1 (Caused by NewConnectionError('<urllib3.connection.VerifiedHTTPSConnection object at 0x7f5b640b4198>: Failed to establish a new connection: [Errno -3] Temporary failure in name resolution',))

 - *OS (if on CLI)*: Ubuntu 16.04
 - *Codalab CLI Version (if on CLI)*: 0.5.8

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior :
1. cl-worker
2. cl run -n predict --request-docker-image lrh000/ubuntu:nlp --request-gpus 2 --request-cpus 2 --request-memory 48g input.json:0xbdd8f3 :wsl_coda 'sh wsl_coda/work_dir/dev_preprocess.sh' (0x5c7f9b)  failed
3. cl run -n predict --request-docker-image lrh000/ubuntu:nlp --request-gpus 2 --request-cpus 2 'nvidia-smi' (0x86a7fe)  ready
4. cl run -n predict --request-docker-image lrh000/ubuntu:nlp --request-gpus 2 --request-cpus 2 :wsl_coda 'nvidia-smi' (0x90db97)  failed, same with step 2.

**Expected behavior**
An explanation of the mechanism for codalabworker to download dependencies and suggestions for improvement

**Additional context**
We think that the slow download of dependencies has led to excessive attempts to obtain images

title: the state is always uploading after choose a big file to upload
[USER ISSUE] --exclude-ignore is only supported by GNU tar library
body:
Mac users cannot run `cl upload [folder]` due to the fact that the default tar library is BSD. 

I think the best fix for now would be to get rid of the default value  of `--ignore` for `cl upload`. I will create a follow up issue to find a better to specify ignore files for BSD tar libraries.

title: [USER ISSUE] Easy to request insufficient memory
body:
**Describe the bug**
No restriction on the minimum memory for run request. When user request insufficient memory by accident (i.e typed 30 in new run panel to request 30 bytes, when the user actually wants 30g) it will crash the docker container and the only solution is to restart the worker

**Expected behavior**
Place a restriction on frontend side, override insufficient memory request on backend side for cli

2. While it is first loading, click "View Source".

body: Try pressing tab and you get a "Cannot read property 'Deferred' of undefined'" error.

title: Worker managers started from `codalab_service` with the rest of the Codalab service crash
body:
When starting the `codalab_service` from scratch, the rest server is not responsive by the time the worker manager containers start, so the worker managers just crash immediately as they can't check in with the server.

The current workaround is to start them later with `codalab-service start -s worker-manager-cpu worker-manager-gpu` but we should have logic that just has them wait for rest server or retrying to log in for some time before crashing.

title: parallel_run_quota doesn't work properly.
body:
The `parallel_run_quota` doesn't seem to work correctly while I was testing the slow transition issue (#1254). 
When I was locally testing the slow transition changes I made, I noticed all the jobs (more than 10) were running at once. However, my user `parallel_run_quota` is 3 fetching from the database. So we need to correct this to avoid one user taking too many resources from the shared system.

title: Problem with disk quota enforcement on workers
body:
A couple issues seen around disk requests:

1- When a bundle goes over its disk quota, it is killed by the worker when that is caught, but the worker still uploads all the results, making the disk quota effectively useless.

2- When the disk quota is the same as the user's total disk quota left, this upload step causes a failure with an unparsable (No JSON could be decoded) error message.

title: Copy tests should not expect file sizes to remain the same
body:
Today, as I was running tests and happened to mount bundles of the two instances used in two-instance tests on separate filesystems, I started having the `copy` tests fail.
Further investigation reveled the following:    
- Copying works, but the test fail because the `data_size` field doesn't match.
- The mismatch is due to directories (not their contents, just directory metadata) being different sizes before and after copying
- Before copying `ls -la` on bundle root prints values like `5` or `7` for many directories, after copying they are always `4096`
- When I do `cl down remote-instance::uuid` and do `ls -la` in the directory, we again see the values like `5` or `7`
- When I do `cl run files:uuid 'cd files && ls -la'`, we see `4096` as the directory size.
- [This](https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/55/what-does-size-of-a-directory-mean-in-output-of-ls-l-command) suggests that these are just directory metadata and may have different size on different filesystems.
- In this case I'm running the tests on the stanford cluster and the temp instance lives on `/tmp` whereas the regular instance lives on `/sailhome` which might be different filesystems.
- I tested this by copying the local copy of the folder to `/tmp` and confirming that its total size changed, matching that seen on the `/tmp` instance.

Hence our tests are wrong and we should not expect the data sizes to remain exactly the same if we copy bundles across two instances.

title: Worksheet markdown parsing of multiline commands
body:
_From @nikhilxb on January 11, 2019 21:46_

**Bug:**
After worksheet opened in the online editor, all runs with multiline command are not parsed int table properly. See https://worksheets.codalab.org/worksheets/0x453913e76b65495d8b9730d41c7e0a0c/

**Temporary fix (Kerem):**
A solution for now is to manually edit the markdown and remove the command in the square braces since those don't affect what's shown on the rendered worksheet
i.e. you can just remove everything in the square brackets,  and the bundle will still display correctly as long as its UUID is in the curly braces

e.g. `[run train-policy -- src:craigslistbargain,train-data:parse-train/parsed.json,dev-data:parse-dev/parsed.json,:nltk_data,:price-tracker/price_tracker.pkl,schema:craigslistbargain-schema : mkdir -p mappings/lf2lf; mkdir -p cache/lf2lf; mkdir -p checkpoint/lf2lf; PYTHONPATH=src python src/main.py --schema-path schema --train-examples-paths train-data --test-examples-paths dev-data \ --price-tracker price-tracker \ --model lf2lf \ --model-path checkpoint/lf2lf --mappings mappings/lf2lf \ --word-vec-size 300 --pretrained-wordvec "" "" \ --rnn-size 300 --rnn-type LSTM --global-attention multibank_general \ --num-context 2 --stateful \ --batch-size 128 --gpuid 0 --optim adagrad --learning-rate 0.01 \ --epochs 30 --report-every 500 \ --cache cache/lf2lf --ignore-cache \ --verbose \ ]{0x7f74f53dfa834cf78228afd18251926c}` can be turned into `[run train-policy ]{0x7f74f53dfa834cf78228afd18251926c}` and it should work

or even `[]{0x7f74f53dfa834cf78228afd18251926c}`

title: Non-bundle worksheet items are counted when resolving index-based bundle references
body:
As reported by Robin, if someone has a worksheet that looks like this:
```
[bundle2]{UUID2}
# Here's a section title
[bundle1]{UUID1}
```
And they run `cl rm ^2` to delete `bundle2`, they'll get a `Bundle None not found` error.
However if they run `cl rm ^3`, `bundle2` will be deleted.

`cl rm ^1` would delete `bundle1` as expected.

This is because when the index `^` is being resolved, it seems to count all worksheet items and not just bundles. So adding a new line before the section title in the example above would make `bundle2` aligned with `^4` instead. 

This seems like it could be related to the worksheet interpretation revamp? @w0nche0l

title: Fix/940 bundle run time
body:
- Make calculation of bundle run time consistent
- Refactor bundle state transition methods

title: Bundle metadata default values appear as 'None'
body:
After our recent bundle metadata changes, some values whose defaults are set server side like:
- docker image: set server-side depending on whether a GPU is requested
- disk & time: set server-side to be whatever the user has left
are initialized as `None` before the `bundle_manager` makes the final decision. However, in the database (and hence in our frontend and in `cl info` calls), these values stay at `None`. We should make sure that these are properly propagated to the database at some point during the lifetime of a bundle.

title: Force worker to exit when authentication error occurs
body:
If worker has an authentication error, then throw an exception that also marks the worker as stopped.  
I'm a little iffy about the implementation on this one, @percyliang @bkgoksel, any suggestions? Is there a cleaner way to achieve this that doesn't use exceptions as a de-facto message passing mechanism?

title: Docker image manager issues
body: Currently we have several issues with the docker image manager that cause big usability issues when they occur together. We should revamp and more thoroughly test the docker image manager.

title: Extremely large docker images are allowed
body:
Currently we have no limits on individual Docker image sizes, this has 2 problems:
1. People can put their data on their Docker image to go over disk quotas
2. If a single image moves disk use above the worker image size limit, the cleanup process get stuck in an infinite loop of trying to remove the image as soon as it is downloaded, and restarting downloads.

We should  enforce individual size limits on Docker images and pass on informative error messages to people who request docker images that are too large.

title: Bundle time use calculation inconsistent
body: Currently the runtime calculation of a bundle is inconsistent. We should clearly define what it should include (including preparing and uploading or only docker container runtime) and be consistent in our display during and after the run and inclusion in user quota.

title: Fixing bug
body:
Fixes bug where the server does not know how to deal with non-list return values from search.
`search_bundle_uuids` will return a single (non-list) number when looking for either a count or a sum; this returns that number as a markdown item, instead of crashing.

title: `cl upload` doesn't throw an error message when upload bigger than user disk quota
body:
Currently the CLI hangs when upload is bigger than user disk quota left, and the upload bundle becomes `failed` with high latency, as reported in [this worksheets issue](https://github.com/codalab/codalab-worksheets/issues/423)

The ideal workflow is to fail the bundle ASAP and also throw an informative error message on the CLI.

title: Flaky stdout/stderr for long running jobs
body:
Some jobs sometimes seem to not update stdout/stderr until the end (or will update them to a point, then stdout/stderr will seem to be frozen until the job ends and they will be populated)

Both cases happened to me and also happened during 224N Codalab submissions.
In one case I tried debugging by entering a shell inside the container running the bundle and read the `/proc/<pid>/fd/1` and `/proc/<pid>/fd/2` of the command running (direct file descriptors to the process' stdout/stderr) and even these seemed to be stuck (one had stopped printing midway).

In another case, the same job running locally would populate its stdout fine.

title: Unable to reserve worker resources for resumed runs
body:
When a worker starts up, it tries to do two things: checkin with the server, and resume previous runs.

There exists a conflict between the two actions:
If the checkin happens first, then the server bundle manager might assign new run bundles to the worker without any regard for the resources taken up by those previous runs, because the rows for them have not yet been inserted into `worker_run`.

If resume previous runs happens first, then the server throws an exception because resuming previous runs involves inserting rows into `worker_run`; but these rows reference a worker that hasn't checked in. This is a foreign reference violation.

title: Worker Run() objects are not resumable
body: Runs can be resumed if the worker dies while the container is running, but if the Run object is interrupted at any other point, the worker will be unable to recover it. This is the reason why a worker that goes offline while one of its bundles are "uploading results" is unrecoverable.

title: Markdown tables don't render correctly

labels.name: p3
labels.description: Do it some day.

body: Worksheets recognize markdown table syntax but table cells are rendered without proper spacing, borders and background coloring.

title: MetadataSpec Default Values are never used
body: fill_missing_metadata() grabs default values from type constructors, ignoring specified default values.

title: Fail bundles immediately if no worker has enough GPUs
Fix security exploit and #824
body: Fixes #824 and security exploit (details redacted)

title: dependency-state.json crashing workers
body:
Somehow these state json files can trip up workers and cause them to crash. May or may not be related to #819. 

Current work around is to delete the file when it happens.

title: Truncated worker_dependency fields angering the bundle service
body:
The bundle service started generating these at about 1Hz:

    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/usr0/codalab/codalab-cli/codalab/worker/bundle_manager.py", line 79, in run
        self._run_iteration()
      File "/usr0/codalab/codalab-cli/codalab/worker/bundle_manager.py", line 99, in _run_iteration
        self._schedule_run_bundles()
      File "/usr0/codalab/codalab-cli/codalab/worker/default_bundle_manager.py", line 25, in _schedule_run_bundles

      File "/usr0/codalab/codalab-cli/codalab/model/worker_model.py", line 146, in get_workers
        } for row in worker_rows}
      File "/usr0/codalab/codalab-cli/codalab/model/worker_model.py", line 146, in <dictcomp>
        } for row in worker_rows}
      File "/usr0/codalab/codalab-cli/codalab/model/worker_model.py", line 94, in _deserialize_dependencies
        return map(tuple, json.loads(blob))
          File "/usr/lib/python2.7/json/__init__.py", line 338, in loads
        return _default_decoder.decode(s)
      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/json/decoder.py", line 366, in decode
        obj, end = self.raw_decode(s, idx=_w(s, 0).end())
      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/json/decoder.py", line 382, in raw_decode
        obj, end = self.scan_once(s, idx)
    ValueError: Unterminated string starting at: line 1 column 65523 (char 65522)

It appears to be a problem with the `worker_dependency` table. Here's an example of a record that causes the issue (xxxxxx):

    mysql> select worker_id, RIGHT(dependencies,20) as deps from worker_dependency;
    +--------------------------+----------------------+
    | worker_id                | deps                 |
    +--------------------------+----------------------+
    | xxxxxx.xxxxxx.xxx(32079) | ",""],["0x9fae534df3 |
    | yyyyyy.yyyyyy.yyy(18668) | []                   |
    +--------------------------+----------------------+
    2 rows in set (0.00 sec)

You can see how the 0x9fae item just trails off and isn't closed properly. This could indicate a problem with the serializer on the `dependencies` field, and/or/since the dependencies list for this particular worker has become too long to store in the table.

If I quit the offending worker, the bundle service stops generating errors. When I bring that worker back up, it gets the same bad dependencies value and the errors start up again.

Is there a way to reset the dependencies for a worker? Can I clear the docker image cache, or something like that? And, any idea what might be causing these long dependency chains? We've run barely any jobs so far, and presumably you folks don't see problems like this in the primary instance even with much greater loads.

title: Fix? Finally?
body: Fix test-cli timeouts on circleci

title: Fix permissions issue
--request-docker-image grabs all versions
body:
Migrated from: https://github.com/codalab/codalab-worksheets/issues/351

Current behavior: `--request-docker-image tensorflow/tensorflow` grabs all versions of tensorflow, which fills up disk space.

Desired behavior: grab only the `:latest` branch and make sure that we pull every time in case the latest tag changes.

title: wrong path for file in output directory
Incorrect session in SSH login shell
body:
An SSH login shell is invoked with a `-` prefix (e.g., `-bash`). This complicates the session computation in the `session_name` method of `lib.codalab_manager.CodaLabManager`.

For reference, here's the relevant portion of the `session_name` method.
```
        # Otherwise, go up process hierarchy to the *highest up shell* out of
        # the consecutive shells.  Include Python and Ruby so we can script from inside them.
        #   cl bash python bash screen bash gnome-terminal init
        #                  ^
        #                  | return this
        # This way, it's easy to write scripts that have embedded 'cl' commands
        # which modify the current session.
        process = psutil.Process(os.getppid())
        session = 'top'
        max_depth = 10
        while process and max_depth:
            name = os.path.basename(process.cmdline()[0])
            if name not in ('sh', 'bash', 'csh', 'tcsh', 'zsh', 'python', 'ruby'):
                break
            session = str(process.pid)
            process = process.parent()
            max_depth = max_depth - 1 
        return session
```

Running a `cl` command on the shell:
`-bash --> sshd --> sshd --> init`
The method exits at `-bash`, so the resulting session is `top`

Running a `cl` command in a python script (or a bash / ruby script):
`python (or bash or ruby) --> -bash --> sshd --> sshd --> init`
The method exits at `-bash`, so the resulting session is the PID of `python`.

Ideally the two sessions should be the same.

title: Foreign key constraint fails on bundle deletion
body:
..even after `cl wait`.

Our monitor (on both wsprod and nlp) have occasionally been reporting that a `cl rm` call fails on a bundle, AFTER a call to `cl wait` on that bundle just completed. The sequence of commands run by the monitor looks like:

     >>> cl run stress-test.pl:<uuid of stress-test script> perl stress-test.pl 5 10 10
     >>> cl wait <uuid of the newly created run bundle>
     >>> cl rm <uuid of stress-test script> <uuid of newly created run bundle>

We also get a simultaneous exception report with MySQL complaining that 
```
Cannot delete or update a parent row: a foreign key constraint fails (`codalab_bundles`.`worker_run`, CONSTRAINT `worker_run_ibfk_3` FOREIGN KEY (`run_uuid`) REFERENCES `bundle` (`uuid`))
```

It looks like the row in the worker_run table that references the run bundle is not yet deleted when the `cl rm` command is issued, causing a foreign key constraint error.

This is strange to me because when I last checked the code, the bundle is marked as completed (status set to 'ready' or 'failed') in the same database transaction as the deletion of the worker_run row, but for some reason `cl wait` is returning before the worker_run row is deleted. Requires further investigation.

title: command too long when logging to events
body:
Noticed these exceptions in the REST server console (after upgrading to Ubuntu 16.04, not sure if that's related):

DataError: (_mysql_exceptions.DataError) (1406, "Data too long for column 'command' at row 1")

According to tables.py, the maximum length of 'command' is 63, which can easily get exceeded by this:

POST /workers/<worker_id>/finalize_bundle/uuid:re:0x[0-9a-f]{32}

We could easily increase the limit from 63 to 255, but it might be better to shorten the command (e.g., to 'finalize_bundle'), because args contains the full information anyway.  Should have generic way of stripping the full POST query.

On a related note, we should filter out non-user events like
POST /workers/<worker_id>/checkin

title: docker environment variables not visible to command
body: Docker images currently can define environment variables, but these are not picked up by CodaLab because we run commands inside `sudo bash -c ...` (see docker_client.py).  The problem is if we don't do sudo, then the files generated by the commands might not be readable by the outside world.  Though this might be okay, as long as we then change the permissions on everything once the run finishes.  The big picture is that any docker container people build should work in CodaLab without any special considerations.

```
failure_msg = 'No response from worker in %s' % time.strftime('%H:%M:%S', time.gmtime(update_timeout))
```

Should use formatting.duration_str for consistency.

2) Major: setting the status of a bundle to FAILED doesn't clean up temp files, do proper accounting, etc.  We need to call update_running_bundle to use the same code path as if a run were actually finishing.

title: Backslashes in table schema regexp are removed after saving
body:
To reproduce, add a table schema

```
% schema hello
% add host remote s/\..*/
```

The second line should strip `juke29.stunford.edu` into `juke29`. However, after saving, the schema is changed into

```
% schema hello
% add host remote s/..*/
```

which replace everything into an empty string. Quoting does not help, and this bug affects both the online editor and the command line editor.

However, the following is fine:

```
% schema hello
% add host remote "s/\..*/ | s/hello/world"
```

With multiple filters, the slash is not removed when saved.

title: FileServer is not thread-safe
body: The FileServer is an asynchronous server that uses the ThreadingMixIn. Each request is executed in a newly created thread. The request handler methods in the FileServer access file_paths, file_handles and other variables without grabbing any lock. Thus, it's possible for modifications of these dictionaries to lead to inconsistent results.

title: Worksheet markdown documentation has unreliable URL
body:
Many parts of CodaLab reference the worksheet markdown documentation using the URL `https://github.com/codalab/codalab-cli/worksheet-syntax.md`, but this URL doesn't actually work on GitHub. (try https://github.com/codalab/codalab-cli/worksheet-syntax.md)

Proposing that we move the markdown documentation to the wiki and updates the links/tutorial worksheets to reflect this.

title: quote arguments to dispatch-q and dispatch-torque
Group db transactions properly
body:
Certain groups of operations should be wrapped in a single transaction.

For example, in `LocalBundleClient.add_worksheet_item()`, information about whether or not the worksheet is frozen is checked in a separate transaction from the transaction in which the items are added to the worksheet.

title: numbering scheme off when we have missing bundles
body:
Create a worksheet with a real bundle and a missing bundle (cl wedit and add a fake bundle uuid).

Then `cl info ^1` will refer to the real bundle rather than the missing one, but `cl ls` will show that ^1 refers to the missing one.  Super confusing!

title: cl upload does not handle filenames with spaces correctly
body:
When I run `cl upload dataset ~/Cloud/.sync/Archive/Documents/SCOr/05-31-15\ SCOr.mp4 -n scorvideo`
I get

```
BundleStore.upload: copying /Users/sckoo/Cloud/.sync/Archive/Documents/SCOr/05-31-15 SCOr.mp4 to /Users/sckoo/.codalab/temp/bbbd76f2a6d249e6ae3d0a3e15448627rsync: link_stat "/Users/sckoo/Cloud/.sync/Archive/Documents/SCOr/05-31-15" failed: No such file or directory (2)
rsync: link_stat "/Users/sckoo/Developer/codalab-cli/SCOr.mp4" failed: No such file or directory (2)
rsync error: some files could not be transferred (code 23) at /SourceCache/rsync/rsync-45/rsync/main.c(992) [sender=2.6.9]
 UsageError: Unable to copy /Users/sckoo/Cloud/.sync/Archive/Documents/SCOr/05-31-15 SCOr.mp4 to: /Users/sckoo/.codalab/temp/bbbd76f2a6d249e6ae3d0a3e15448627
```

Maybe this has something to do with how arguments are passed to rsync?

title: Search with .sum keyword fails on bundle metadata
body:
The "search" test in `test-cli.py` fails. 

Moreover, the following will always output a large integer that I can't seem to identify:

```
cl search name=test data_size=.sum
cl search name=test description=.sum
cl search name=test name=.sum
```

title: Cache bundle contents

labels.name: p3
labels.description: Do it some day.

body: cl print and rendering on the website is slow for worksheets because rendering each worksheet requires going to disk and reading everything out.  If all the bundles on a worksheet are 'ready', then we should cache the rendered version so that things load much faster.

title: make sure that run -t, wait -t work
body: Currently, some output gets cut off.  Make sure we preserve the full contents.

title: report time, memory correctly
body:
Currently, time and memory estimates are not being reported correctly.
With docker it's a bit tricky, because we need to get a handle of the process running in the docker container, not just the 'docker run' process.

title: clean up used docker containers
body: When using the monitor.py script, docker containers don't seem to get removed properly, resulting in an overflowing number of containers.  This only seems to happen on the Stanford machines (jude44).

title: clean up temp files
body: When things fail, temp files (in .codalab/temp and /tmp) don't seen to be cleaned up properly.

title: non-existent file directives
body:
If use 
% display contents /file
and /file doesn't exist, then an exception is thrown.  Should just return the empty string or n/a (since the file might not have been created).

title: allow cl upload urls with ? in the url
body:
Ticket https://github.com/codalab/codalab/issues/783 was fixed on the front end but the backend rejects it because the name comes from the url when creating an uploaded bundle. 

You also get an error if doing it via command line
`cl upload http://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=V9UPN45u

Solution: strip characters in the URL that are not allowed in names.
